meanings.definition: To use one's authority to reject or cancel a decision
meanings.sent1: The teacher had to override the student's request to leave early.
meanings.sent2: The manager can override any changes made without approval.
meanings.sent3: The robot tried to override the command to stop and kept moving forward.
meanings.sent4: His determination to win was so strong that it seemed to override any obstacles in his way.
meanings.sent5: The superhero's willpower was able to override the mind control device.

meanings.sent1: In the end, kindness will always override cruelty.
meanings.sent2: The team's hard work will override any lack of experience.
meanings.sent3: The cat's desire for attention seemed to override the dog's need for a nap.
meanings.sent4: The beauty of the sunset seemed to override any worries in her mind.
meanings.sent5: The laughter of children can override the silence of a room.

meanings.sent1: The judge decided to override the previous ruling and grant a new trial.
meanings.sent2: The company policy allows the manager to override any expired contracts.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick was to override the audience's memory of the card they picked.
meanings.sent4: The storm was so powerful that it seemed to override any attempts to control it.
meanings.sent5: The love for her family could override any disagreements they had.

meanings.sent1: The new software will override the old system completely.
meanings.sent2: The digital version will override the need for physical copies.
meanings.sent3: The excitement of the upcoming event seemed to override any worries about the past.
meanings.sent4: The new leader's vision will override the outdated practices of the past.
meanings.sent5: The modern technology will override the need for manual labor.
